question: [File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: get_public_key()] [Version race condition] Between get_public_key() returning the current version and sign() using it, can rotation occur, causing signature with wrong version? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: rotate_key()] [Incomplete old key deletion] After rotation, if the old private key remains in storage, can filesystem scanning or memory dumps recover it for use in attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: export_private_key_for_version()] [Version enumeration oracle] Can an attacker enumerate all stored key versions by trying different version parameters, learning the complete key rotation history? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: get_public_key_previous_version()] [Only two versions maintained] The specification says 'at most two versions', but can attackers exploit this limit to force key history loss by triggering rapid rotations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: rotate_key()] [Rotation without consensus] If a validator rotates their key unilaterally without updating on-chain validator info, can this cause consensus failures or allow equivocation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: sign_using_version()] [Cross-version replay] Can an attacker replay a signature created with an old version as if it were created with the current version, confusing consensus validators? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: export_private_key_for_version()] [Version parameter validation] Does this function validate that the provided version (public key) actually corresponds to the named key, or can attackers provide arbitrary public keys? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: rotate_key()] [Key rotation frequency limits] Are there rate limits on key rotation? Can an attacker rapidly rotate keys to cause performance degradation or storage exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: get_public_key_previous_version()] [Version timestamp validation] Are version timestamps validated? Can attackers manipulate timestamps to make old versions appear current? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: sign_using_version()] [Version downgrade forced] Can a Byzantine validator force other validators to accept signatures from old key versions by claiming their current key is unavailable? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: rotate_key()] [Rotation notification failure] After successful key rotation, if notification to consensus components fails, can validators continue using the old key while storage has the new key? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: export_private_key_for_version()] [Version export timing attack] Can measuring the time to export different versions leak information about which versions exist or key derivation relationships? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: get_public_key()] [Public key response tampering] Can the PublicKeyResponse with last_update timestamp be tampered with to make old keys appear freshly rotated? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: set()] [Concurrent write race] Can two threads write to the same namespaced key simultaneously, causing data corruption or inconsistent state across the storage backend? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: get()] [TOCTOU vulnerability] Between calling get() to read a key and using the returned value, can another thread modify the key, causing time-of-check-time-of-use race conditions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: create_key()] [Double-checked locking bug] If create_key() uses double-checked locking to avoid creating duplicate keys, can race conditions still allow multiple keys to be created? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: rotate_key()] [Concurrent rotation conflict] If two threads call rotate_key() simultaneously, can both succeed, creating ambiguity about which key is the current version? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: sign()] [Concurrent signature generation] Can concurrent sign() calls on the same key interfere with each other, potentially leaking key material through timing channels or state corruption? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Struct: Namespaced] [Non-atomic namespace access] Are namespace and inner fields accessed atomically? Can partial updates during concurrent modifications cause inconsistent state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: export_private_key()] [Concurrent export during rotation] If export_private_key() is called concurrently with rotate_key(), can it return a partially rotated or corrupted key? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: import_private_key()] [Import during active use] If import_private_key() is called while another thread is using the key for signing, can this cause crashes or signature failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: get_public_key()] [Stale cache read] If storage uses caching, can get_public_key() return stale cached values during concurrent rotation, causing signature verification failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: set()] [Write-write conflict] If two namespaces independently write to keys that collide after hashing, can writes to one namespace corrupt data in another? (High)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: available()] [Concurrent availability check] Can concurrent calls to available() during storage backend failover cause inconsistent results and validator state divergence? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/secure/storage/src/namespaced.rs] [Function: reset_and_clear()] [Clear during active operations] If reset_and_clear() is called while other threads are performing cryptographic operations, can this cause use-after-free or null pointer dereferences? (Critical)
